{{Infobox protected area | name = Albert E. Sleeper State Park | designation = [[List of Michigan state parks|Michigan State Park]] | iucn_category = III | photo = | photo_caption = | photo_width = 280 | map = USA Michigan | map_caption = Location in Michigan | map_width = 280 | location = Lower Peninsula, [[Huron County, Michigan]] USA | nearest_city = [[Caseville, Michigan]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|58|24|N|83|12|16|W|region:US-MI|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | elevation = {{convert|600|ft}} {{cite gnis|619903|Albert E State Park}} | area = {{convert|723|acre|ha}} | established = 1925 County Park
1927 Huron State Park
1944 Albert E. Sleeper State Park | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Michigan Department of Natural Resources]] | website = [http://www.michigandnr.com/parksandtrails/Details.aspx?id=494&type=SPRK Albert E. Sleeper State Park] }} '''Albert E. Sleeper State Park''' is a public recreation area on [[Lake Huron]] in [[Lake Township, Huron County, Michigan|Lake Township]], [[Huron County, Michigan|Huron County]], [[Michigan]]. The [[state park]] encompasses {{convert|723|acre}} four miles northeast of [[Caseville, Michigan|Caseville]], close to the tip of [[The Thumb]] of Michigan. ==History== The park was created in 1925 by Huron County; it became a state park in 1927. The [[Civilian Conservation Corps]] was active in the park in the 1940s, building the park's Outdoor Center. In 1944, the park was renamed to honor former [[Governor of Michigan|Michigan Governor]] [[Albert E. Sleeper]], who signed the legislation authorizing the state park system. ;Economic analysis According to a 2008 economic impact analysis, Albert E. Sleeper State Park has a significant effect on the economy of the surrounding county, accounting for $5.476 million in direct spending, 144 direct jobs, and $2.881 million in [[value added]]. There is additional economic effect from [[multiplier effect|secondary effects]], totaling $7.905 million (44.9 percent over direct spending), 181 jobs (25.7 percent over direct job impacts), and $4.396 million (52.6 percent over direct value added). ==Activities and amenities== The park is considered a multi-use park with recreational features that include a half-mile beach on [[Saginaw Bay]], four miles of trails for hiking, biking and cross-country skiing, picnicking areas, cabins, and campground. ==Notes== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.michigandnr.com/parksandtrails/Details.aspx?id=494&type=SPRK |title=Sleeper State Park |publisher=Michigan Department of Natural Resources |accessdate=March 19, 2018}} {{cite web |url=http://www.michigan.gov/documents/dnr/sleeper_sp_ph1_general_mgmt_plan_397689_7.pdf |title=General Management Plan: Sleeper State Park |publisher=Michigan Department of Natural Resources |pp=A-7, A-33–A-34 |date=September 2011 |accessdate=January 10, 2014}} }} == External links == *[http://www.michigandnr.com/parksandtrails/Details.aspx?id=494&type=SPRK Sleeper State Park] Michigan Department of Natural Resources *[http://www.michigandnr.com/Publications/PDFS/RecreationCamping/sleeper_map.pdf Sleeper State Park Map] Michigan Department of Natural Resources *[https://www.protectedplanet.net/sleeper-state-park Sleeper State Park] Protected Planet {{Michigan state parks}} [[Category:State parks of Michigan]] [[Category:Protected areas of Huron County, Michigan]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 1925]] [[Category:Saginaw Bay]] [[Category:Civilian Conservation Corps in Michigan]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:Auxetische Materialien.wiki.png|thumb|400px]]
'''Auxetics''' are [[structure]]s or [[material science|materials]] that have a negative [[Poisson's ratio]]. When stretched, they become thicker perpendicular to the applied force. This occurs due to their particular internal structure and the way this deforms when the sample is uniaxially loaded. Auxetics can be single [[molecule]]s, crystals, or a particular structure of macroscopic matter. Such materials and structures are expected to have mechanical properties such as high [[Shock absorber|energy absorption]] and [[fracture]] resistance. Auxetics may be useful in applications such as [[Ballistic vest|body armor]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Hook's law |url=https://www.economist.com/news/technology-quarterly/21567203-materials-auxetic-substances-which-get-fatter-rather-thinner-when-stretched|accessdate=1 March 2013 | work=The Economist|date=1 December 2012}}</ref> packing material, knee and elbow pads, robust shock absorbing material, and sponge mops.
The term ''auxetic'' derives from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word αὐξητικός (auxetikos) which means "that which tends to increase" and has its root in the word αὔξησις, or ''auxesis'', meaning "increase" (noun). This terminology was coined by Professor Ken Evans of the [[University of Exeter]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Quinion | first = Michael | title = Auxetic | date = 1996-11-09 | url = http://www.worldwidewords.org/turnsofphrase/tp-aux1.htm | accessdate = 2009-01-02}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Evans | first = Ken | title = Auxetic polymers: a new range of materials. | journal = Endeavour 15.4 | date = 1991 | pages = 170–174 | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/016093279190123S | accessdate = 2017-05-08 | doi=10.1016/0160-9327(91)90123-S | volume=15| issue = 4 }}.</ref> One of the first artificially produced auxetic materials, the RFS structure (diamond-fold structure) , was invented in 1978 by the Berlin researcher K. Pietsch. Although he did not use the term auxetics, he describes for the first time the underlying lever mechanism and its non-linear mechanical reaction is therefore considered the inventor of the auxetic net. The earliest published example of a material with negative Poisson's constant is due to A. G. Kolpakov in 1985, "Determination of the average characteristics of elastic frameworks"; the next synthetic auxetic material was described in ''Science'' in 1987, entitled "[[Foam]] structures with a Negative Poisson's Ratio" <ref name="Lakes">{{Citation | last = Lakes | first = R.S. | title = Foam structures with a negative Poisson's ratio | journal = Science | volume = 235 | issue = 4792 | pages = 1038–40 | date = 1987-02-27 | doi = 10.1126/science.235.4792.1038 | postscript =. | pmid = 17782252|bibcode = 1987Sci...235.1038L }}</ref> by R.S. Lakes from the [[University of Wisconsin Madison]]. The use of the word ''auxetic'' to refer to this property probably began in 1991.<ref>{{Citation | last = Evans | first = Ken| title = Auxetic polymers: a new range of materials| date = 1991 | doi=10.1016/0160-9327(91)90123-S | volume=15 | issue = 4| journal=Endeavour | pages=170–174}}.</ref>
Designs of composites with inverted hexagonal periodicity cell (auxetic hexagon), possessing negative Poisson ratios, were published in 1985.<ref name="Kolpakov">{{cite journal | last1 = Kolpakov | first1 = A.G. | year =1985 | title = Determination of the average characteristics of elastic frameworks | url = | journal = Journal of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics | volume = 49 | issue = 6| pages = 739–745 | doi=10.1016/0021-8928(85)90011-5|bibcode = 1985JApMM..49..739K }}</ref><ref name="Almgren">{{cite journal | last1 = Almgren | first1 = R.F. | year = 1985 | title = An isotropic three-dimensional structure with Poisson's ratio=-1 | url = | journal = J. Elasticity | volume = 15 | issue = 4| pages = 427–430 | doi=10.1007/bf00042531}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Theocaris | first1 = P.S. | last2 = Stavroulakis | first2 = G.E. | last3 = Panagiotopoulos | first3 = P.D. | year = 1997 | title = Negative Poisson's ratio in composites with star-shaped inclusions: a numerical homogenization approach . | url = | journal = Archive of Applied Mechanics | volume = 67 | issue = 4| pages = 274–286 | doi=10.1007/s004190050117|bibcode = 1997AAM....67..274T }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Theocaris | first1 = P.S. | last2 = Stavroulakis | first2 = G.E. | year = | title = The homogenization method for the study of variation of Poisson's ratio in fiber composites | url = | journal = Archive of Applied Mechanics | volume = 69 | issue = 3–4| pages = 281–295 }}</ref><ref name="Stavroulakis1">{{cite journal | last1 = Stavroulakis | first1 = G.E. | year = 2005| title = Auxetic behaviour: Appearance and engineering applications | url = | journal = Physica Status Solidi B | volume = 242 | issue = 3| pages = 710–720 | doi=10.1002/pssb.200460388|bibcode = 2005PSSBR.242..710S }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Kaminakis | first1 = N.T. | last2 = Stavroulakis | first2 = G.E. | year = 2012| title = Topology optimization for compliant mechanisms, using evolutionary-hybrid algorithms and application to the design of auxetic materials | url = | journal = Composites Part B: Engineering | volume = 43 | issue = 6| pages = 2655–2668 | doi=10.1016/j.compositesb.2012.03.018}}</ref>
Typically, auxetic materials have low [[density]], which is what allows the hinge-like areas of the auxetic microstructures to flex.<ref>[https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg15420854.200-a-stretch-of-the-imagination.html A stretch of the imagination - 7 June 1997 - New Scientist Space<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
At the macroscale, auxetic behaviour can be illustrated with an [[Inelastic collision|inelastic]] string wound around an elastic cord. When the ends of the structure are pulled apart, the inelastic string straightens while the elastic cord stretches and winds around it, increasing the structure's effective volume. Auxetic behaviour at the macroscale can also be employed for the development of products with enhanced characteristics such as footwear based on the auxetic rotating triangles structures developed by Grima and Evans.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grima|first=JN|last2=Evans|first2=KE|year=2000|title=Auxetic behavior from rotating squares|journal=Journal of Materials Science Letters|volume=19|issue=17|pages=1563–1565|doi=10.1023/A:1006781224002}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grima|first=JN|last2=Evans|first2=KE|year=2006|title=Auxetic behavior from rotating triangles|journal=Journal of Materials Science|volume=41|issue=10|pages=3193–3196|doi=10.1007/s10853-006-6339-8|bibcode = 2006JMatS..41.3193G }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.nike.com/news/nike-free-2016-running-training|title=Nike Free 2016 product press release|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Examples of auxetic materials include: * Auxetic [[polyurethane]] foam<ref>{{cite journal | last=Li | first=Yan | last2=Zeng | first2=Changchun |title = On the successful fabrication of auxetic polyurethane foams: Materials requirement, processing strategy and conversion mechanism | journal = Polymer | year = 2016 |doi=10.1016/j.polymer.2016.01.076| volume=87 |pages=98–107}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Li | first=Yan | last2=Zeng | first2=Changchun | title = Room‐Temperature, Near‐Instantaneous Fabrication of Auxetic Materials with Constant Poisson's Ratio over Large Deformation | journal = Advanced Materials | year = 2016 |doi=10.1002/adma.201505650| pmid=26861805 | volume=28 | issue=14 | pages=2822–2826 }}</ref> * [[Cristobalite|α-Cristobalite]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yeganeh-Haeri|first=Amir|last2=Weidner|first2=Donald J.|last3=Parise|first3=John B.|date=1992-07-31|title=Elasticity of α-Cristobalite: A Silicon Dioxide with a Negative Poisson's Ratio|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/257/5070/650|journal=Science|language=en|volume=257|issue=5070|pages=650–652|doi=10.1126/science.257.5070.650|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17740733|bibcode = 1992Sci...257..650Y }}</ref> * Certain rocks and minerals<ref name="burke">{{Citation | last = Burke | first = Maria | title = A stretch of the imagination | journal = New Scientist | volume = 154 | issue = 2085 | page = 36 | date = 1997-06-07 | url = https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg15420854.200-a-stretch-of-the-imagination.html}}</ref> * [[Graphene]], which can be made auxetic through the introduction of vacancy defects<ref>{{cite journal |last=Grima |first=J. N. |last2=Winczewski |first2=S. |last3=Mizzi |first3=L. |last4=Grech |first4=M. C. |last5=Cauchi |first5=R. |last6=Gatt |first6=R. |last7=Attard |first7=D. |last8=Wojciechowski |first8=K.W. |last9=Rybicki |first9=J. |title=Tailoring Graphene to Achieve Negative Poisson's Ratio Properties |doi=10.1002/adma.201404106 |pmid=25504060 |journal=Advanced Materials |year=2014 |volume=27 |issue=8 |pages=1455–1459}}</ref> * Living bone tissue (although this is only suspected)<ref name="burke"/> * Tendons within their normal range of motion.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gatt R, Vella Wood M, Gatt A, Zarb F, Formosa C, Azzopardi KM, Casha A, Agius TP, Schembri-Wismayer P, Attard L, Chockalingam N, Grima JN | title = Negative Poisson's ratios in tendons: An unexpected mechanical response | journal = Acta Biomater. | year = 2015 | doi = 10.1016/j.actbio.2015.06.018 | pmid = 26102335 | volume=24 | pages=201–208}}</ref> * Specific variants of [[polytetrafluorethylene]] polymers such as [[Gore-Tex]]<ref>{{Citation | title = Auxetic materials | url = http://www.azom.com/details.asp?ArticleID=168 | accessdate = 2009-01-02| date = 2001-03-09 }}.</ref> * Paper, all types. If a paper is stretched in an in-plane direction it will expand in its thickness direction due to its network structure.<ref>Baum et al. 1984, Tappi journal, Öhrn, O. E. (1965): Thickness variations of paper on stretching, Svensk Papperstidn. 68(5), 141.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Verma | first=Prateek | last2=Shofner | first2=ML | last3=Griffin |first3=AC | title = Deconstructing the auxetic behavior of paper | journal = Physica Status Solidi B | year = 2013 | doi = 10.1002/pssb.201384243 | volume=251 | issue=2 | pages=289–296|bibcode = 2014PSSBR.251..289V }}</ref> * Several types of origami folds like the Diamond-Folding-Structure (RFS), the [[Herringbone pattern|herringbone]]-fold-structure (FFS) or the [[miura fold]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.markschenk.com/research/files/PhD%20thesis%20-%20Mark%20Schenk.pdf|title=Folded Shell Structures, PhD Thesis|last=Mark|first=Schenk|publisher=University of Cambridge, Clare College|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | url=http://www.nature.com/articles/srep05979 | doi=10.1038/srep05979| pmid=25099402| pmc=4124469| title=Origami based Mechanical Metamaterials| journal=Scientific Reports| volume=4| pages=5979| year=2015| last1=Lv| first1=Cheng| last2=Krishnaraju| first2=Deepakshyam| last3=Konjevod| first3=Goran| last4=Yu| first4=Hongyu| last5=Jiang| first5=Hanqing}}</ref> and other periodic patterns derived from it.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Unraveling metamaterial properties in zigzag-base folded sheets|url = http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/1/8/e1500224|journal = Science Advances|date = 2015|issn = 2375-2548|pages = e1500224|volume = 1|issue = 8|doi = 10.1126/sciadv.1500224|first = Maryam|last = Eidini|first2 = Glaucio H.|last2 = Paulino|arxiv = 1502.05977 |bibcode = 2015SciA....1E0224E|pmid=26601253|pmc=4643767}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eidini|first=Maryam|title=Zigzag-base folded sheet cellular mechanical metamaterials|journal=Extreme Mechanics Letters|volume=6|pages=96–102|doi=10.1016/j.eml.2015.12.006|year=2016|arxiv=1509.08104}}</ref> *Tailored structures designed to exhibit special designed Poisson's ratios.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Tailored 3D Mechanical Metamaterials Made by Dip-in Direct-Laser-Writing Optical Lithography|author=Tiemo Bückmann|display-authors=etal|doi=10.1002/adma.201200584|volume=24|issue=20|journal=Advanced Materials|pages=2710–2714|pmid=22495906|date=May 2012}}</ref> *Chain organic molecules. Recent researches revealed that organic crystals like n-[[Alkane|paraffins]] and similar to them may demonstrate an auxetic behavior.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Stetsenko | first1 = M | year = 2015 | title = Determining the elastic constants of hydrocarbons of heavy oil products using molecular dynamics simulation approach | journal = Journal of Petroleum Science and Engineering | volume = 126 | issue = | pages = 124–130 | doi = 10.1016/j.petrol.2014.12.021 }}</ref> * Processed needle-punched nonwoven fabrics. Due to the network structure of such fabrics, a processing protocol using heat and pressure can convert ordinary (not auxetic) nonwovens into auxetic ones.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Verma | first=Prateek | last2=Lin | first2=A | last3=Wagner | first3=KB | last4=Shofner | first4=ML | last5=Griffin |first5=AC | title = Inducing out-of-plane auxetic behavior in needle-punched nonwovens | journal = Physica Status Solidi B | year = 2015 | doi = 10.1002/pssb.201552036 | volume=252 | issue=7 | pages=1455–1464|bibcode = 2015PSSBR.252.1455V }}</ref> * [[Cork (material)|Cork]] has an almost zero Poisson's ratio. This makes it a good material for sealing wine bottles.<ref name ="Stavroulakis1" /> [[File:Athletic Footwear with Auxetic Sole.jpg|thumb|In footwear, auxetic design allows the sole to expand in size while walking or running, thereby increasing flexibility.]]
==See also== * [[Acoustic metamaterials]] * [[Mechanical metamaterials]] * [[Metamaterials]] * [[Zetix]], a type of commercially manufactured auxetic material * [[Hexagonal parallelogon]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}}
The '''Birds Directive''' (formally known as '''Council Directive 2009/147/EC on the conservation of wild birds''') is a [[European Union directive]] adopted in 2009. It replaces Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds which was modified several times and had become very unclear. It aims to protect all European wild birds and the habitats of listed species, in particular through the designation of [[Special Protection Area]]s (often known by the acronym SPA).
The Birds Directive is one of the EU's two directives in relation to wildlife and nature conservation, the other being the [[Habitats Directive]]. The Habitats Directive led to the setting up of a network of [[Special Areas of Conservation]], which together with the existing Special Protection Areas form a network of protected sites across the [[European Union]] called [[Natura 2000]].
==See also== * [[Conservation movement]] * [[List of European Union directives]]
==References== * Jan-Henrik Meyer: 2010. ''Saving Migrants: a Transnational Network supporting Supranational Bird Protection Policy in the 1970's.'' In Transnational Networks in Regional Integration. Informal Governance in Europe 1945–83, edited by W. Kaiser, M. Gehler and B. Leucht. Basingstoke. Palgrave, 176–198. {{ISBN|978-0-230-24169-5}}, {{ISBN|0-230-24169-7}}. * Jan-Henrik Meyer: ''Zivilgesellschaftliche Mobilisierung und die frühe europäische Umweltpolitik. Die Vogelschutzrichtlinie der Europäischen Gemeinschaften von 1979.'' In: Themenportal Europäische Geschichte (2013), URL: http://www.europa.clio-online.de/2013/Article=588.
== External links== * [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31979L0409:EN:NOT Council Directive 79/409/EEC of 2 April 1979 on the conservation of wild birds] (Official text of the old directive on [[EUR-Lex]]) * [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:71979L0409:EN:NOT National execution measures of the old directive] * [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32009L0147:EN:NOT Directive 2009/147/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 November 2009 on the conservation of wild birds] (Official text on [[EUR-Lex]]) * [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:72009L0147:EN:NOT National execution measures of the new directive] * [http://ec.europa.eu/environment/nature/legislation/birdsdirective/ A page about the Birds Directive] at the [[European Commission]]s website * [http://www.jncc.gov.uk/page-1374 A page about the Birds Directive at the JNCC's website]

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Cooks' Cottage | native_name = Captain Cook's Cottage | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Melbourne Capt Cooks Cottage - outer00.jpg | image_upright = | alt = Cooks' Cottage | caption = | map_type = | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|37|48|52.16|S|144|58|46.02|E|region:AU-VIC_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline,title}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1934|10|15|df=y}}<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article35011609 |title=CAPTAIN COOK'S' COTTAGE HANDED OVER : Presented To Victoria By Mr. Russell Grimwade: "PRECIOUS RELIC SET IN OLD=WORLD GARDEN"|newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=16 October 1934 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=16 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article91079299 |title=CAPTAIN COOK'S COTTAGE: Presented To Victoria By Mr. Russell Grimwade |newspaper=[[The Chronicle (Adelaide)|The Chronicle]] |volume=LXXVII |issue=40,166 |location=Adelaide |date=18 October 1934 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=49 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | author1=Mr Cyril Noisette | author2=Captain James Cook RN | author3=Captain Cooks Cottage | title=Booklet - Victoria Centenary Souvenir, 1934-1935 | publication-date=1934 | publisher=Museum Victoria | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/207477414 | accessdate=6 September 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title=Souvenir of the unveiling of the memorial to Captain James Cook : erected on the site formerly occupied by his cottage at Great Ayton, Yorks, by Mrs R. Linton ... : Monday the 15th day of October, 1934 at 3pm | publication-date=1934 | publisher=County Borough of Middlesbrough | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/12773983 | accessdate=6 September 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11771259 |title=Deeds of Captain Cook's Cottage |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |issue=27,801 |location=Melbourne|date=26 September 1935 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = [[Fitzroy Gardens, Melbourne]], Australia<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article203365193 |title=CAPT. COOK'S COTTAGE. FITZROY GARDENS SITE CHOSEN. |newspaper=[[The Age]] |issue=24,551 |location=Melbourne|date=19 December 1933 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=8 |via=National Library of Australia}}, ''... they had decided against the National Gallery site, which was wholly unsuitable...''</ref> | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | executive_director = | leader_type = | leader = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/cookscottage}} | embedded = }} '''Cooks' Cottage''', previously known as '''Captain Cook's Cottage''',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/24/captain-cooks-cottage-vandalised-with-graffiti-referencing-australia-day|title=Captain Cook's cottage vandalised with graffiti referencing Australia Day|first=Helen|last=Davidson|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=23 January 2014|accessdate=6 August 2017}}</ref> is located in the [[Fitzroy Gardens, Melbourne]], Australia. The cottage was constructed in 1755 in the English village of [[Great Ayton]], [[North Yorkshire]], by the parents of Captain [[James Cook]], James and Grace Cook,<ref name="Cooks Log">[http://www.captaincooksociety.com/ccsu4110.htm The Captain Cook Society: Cook's Log, page 212, volume 6, number 3 (1983).]</ref> and was brought to Melbourne in 1934 by Sir Russell Grimwade.<ref name="CityMelb">{{cite web|url=https://whatson.melbourne.vic.gov.au/PlacesToGo/CooksCottage/Pages/CooksCottage.aspx|title=Cooks' Cottage|publisher=[[City of Melbourne]]|accessdate=6 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4746055 |title=CAPTAIN COOK'S COTTAGE. :ANOTHER CENTENARY GIFT.:Mr. Russell Grimwade's Generosity.|newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |issue=27,105 |location=Melbourne|date=1 July 1933 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=21 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> It is a point of conjecture among historians whether James Cook, the famous navigator, ever lived in the house, but almost certainly he visited his parents at the house.<ref name="Cooks Log"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article203356690 |title=CAPTAIN COOK'S COTTAGE : AN AMAZING SITUATION.|newspaper=[[The Age]] |issue=24,537 |location=Victoria, Australia |date=2 December 1933 |accessdate=6 September 2017 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}}, ''...The house in which Captain Cook was born at Marton-in-Cleveland...in which he lived until...eight years old. was demolished in 1786. '''Until it was pulled down people spoke of it as Captain Cook's cottage.''' Upon the spot where it stood there stands a memorial in the form of a granite vase. It is in Stewart Park, at Marton. By a deed of gift this park was made over to the Middlebrough(sic) council, one of the conditions being "that the monument recording the site of Captain Cook's cottage should for ever be preserved and remain in situ."...''</ref>
The inside of the cottage includes centuries-old antiques and is stylised in the way of the 18th century, as are the clothes of the volunteer guides.<ref name="CityMelb"/>
==History== In 1933 the owner of the cottage decided to sell it with a condition of sale that the building remain in England. She was persuaded to change "England" to "the Empire", and accepted an Australian bid of £800, by [[Russell Grimwade]], as opposed to the highest local offer of £300.<ref name="Cooks Log"/><ref>{{Citation | author1=McCubbin, Maryanne | title=Cooked to perfection: Cooks' Cottage and the exemplary historical figure | journal=Journal of Popular Culture | publication-date=1999-06-22 | publisher=Blackwell Publishers Ltd | volume=33 | issue=1 | pages=35(1) | issn=0022-3840 }}</ref>
The cottage was deconstructed brick by brick and packed into 253 cases and 40 barrels for shipping on board the ''Port Dunedin'' from [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]]. Cuttings from ivy that adorned the house were also taken and planted when the house was re-erected in Melbourne. Grimwade, a notable businessman and philanthropist, donated the house to the people of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] for the centenary anniversary of the settlement of Melbourne in October 1934.<ref name="Cooks Log"/>
The cottage immediately became a popular tourist attraction. In 1978 further restoration work was carried out on the cottage. An English [[cottage garden]] has been established around the house, further adding to its period reconstruction. Very few of the items in the house are from the Cook family, but all are representative furnishings of the period.
==In popular culture== The cottage features in two scenes of the 2012 movie ''[[Any Questions for Ben?]]''<ref>[http://lightfm.com.au/topics/movie-reviews/movie-review-any-questions-for-ben/ Movie review: Any Questions For Ben?], 25 February 2012, 89.9 LightFM, ''... It is great to take note of the locations – Captain Cook's Cottage, the National Gallery of Victoria, and the Yarra River...''</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Cooks' Cottage Inside 01.jpg| Cooks' Cottage Inside 03.jpg| Cooks' Cottage Inside 04.jpg| Cooks' Cottage Inside 05.jpg| </gallery>
==See also== * [[Stewart Park, Middlesbrough]] – site of the cottage where Captain James Cook was born.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/cookscottage}}
{{Captain James Cook}} {{MuseumVictoria}}

page.title: Electron configurations of the elements (data page)

revision.text:
{{main|Electron configuration}} This page shows the [[electron configuration]]s of the neutral gaseous atoms in their ground states. For each atom the subshells are given first in concise form, then with all subshells written out, followed by the number of electrons per shell. Electron configurations of elements beyond [[hassium]] (element 108) are predicted. __NOTOC__ As an approximate rule, electron configurations are given by the [[Electron configuration#Atoms: Aufbau principle and Madelung rule|Aufbau principle and the Madelung rule]]. However there are numerous exceptions; for example the lightest exception is chromium, which would be predicted to have the configuration {{nowrap|1=1s<sup>2</sup> 2s<sup>2</sup> 2p<sup>6</sup> 3s<sup>2</sup> 3p<sup>6</sup> 3d<sup>4</sup> 4s<sup>2</sup>}}, written as {{nowrap|1=[Ar] 3d<sup>4</sup> 4s<sup>2</sup>}}, but whose actual configuration given in the table below is {{nowrap|1=[Ar] 3d<sup>5</sup> 4s<sup>1</sup>}}.

===Hoffman, Lee, and Pershina=== {{cite book| title = The Chemistry of the Actinide and Transactinide Elements| editor1-last = Morss|editor2-first = Norman M.| editor2-last = Edelstein| editor3-last = Fuger|editor3-first = Jean| last1 = Hoffman|first1 = Darleane C.|last2=Lee |first2=Diana M. |last3=Pershina |first3=Valeria |chapter = Transactinides and the future elements| publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media]]| year = 2006| isbn = 1-4020-3555-1| location = Dordrecht, The Netherlands| edition = 3rd| ref = CITEREFHaire2006| page=1722}}
This book contains predicted electron configurations for the elements 119–172 and 184, based on relativistic Dirac–Fock calculations by B. Fricke in {{cite journal |last1=Fricke |first1=B. |editor-last=Dunitz |editor-first=J. D. |year=1975 |journal=Structure and Bonding |volume=21 |pages=89–144 |title=Superheavy elements a prediction of their chemical and physical properties|publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=Berlin |doi=10.1007/BFb0116496}}
===Fricke=== Predicted electron configurations for element 173 based on relativistic Dirac–Fock calculations by B. {{See also|Electricity sector in Canada}} {{Pie chart | thumb =right | caption =Canada total primary energy consumption by fuel in 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2016/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2016-full-report.pdf|title=Statistical Review of World Energy (June 2016)|author=|date=|website=bp.com|accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref> | other = | label1 =Coal | value1 =6 | color1 =#313c42 | label2 =Natural Gas | value2 =28 | color2 =#ef8e39 | label3 =Hydro | value3 =26 | color3 =#005CE6 | label4 =Nuclear | value4 =7 | color4 =#de2821 | label5 =Oil | value5 =31 | color5 =#7C6250 | label6 =Others ([[Renewables|Renew.]]) | value6 =2 | color6 =#00CC4B }} {{Economy of Canada}} Canada has access to all main sources of energy including [[Oil and Gas|oil and gas]], [[coal]], [[hydropower]], [[biomass]], [[Solar power|solar]], [[Geothermal energy|geothermal]], [[Wind power|wind]], [[Marine energy|marine]] and [[Nuclear power|nuclear]]. It is the world's second largest producer of [[uranium]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.world-nuclear.org/information-library/nuclear-fuel-cycle/mining-of-uranium/world-uranium-mining-production.aspx|title=World Nuclear Mining Production|last=|first=|date=19 May 2016|website=World Nuclear Mining|publisher=|access-date=19 June 2016}}</ref> third largest producer of hydro-electricity,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://canadahydro.ca/facts/by-the-numbers/|title=Canadian Hydropower By the Numbers|last=|first=|date=|website=Canadian Hydropower Association|publisher=|access-date=19 June 2016}}</ref> fourth largest natural gas producer, and the fifth largest producer of crude oil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nrcan.gc.ca/sites/www.nrcan.gc.ca/files/energy/files/pdf/EnergyFactBook2015-Eng_Web.pdf|title=Energy Fact Book 2015-2016|last=|first=|date=2015|website=Natural Resources Canada|publisher=|access-date=19 June 2016}}</ref> Only [[Russia]], the [[People's Republic of China]], the [[United States]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] produce more total energy than Canada.<ref name="CEF_GC">{{cite web|title=Canadian Energy Facts |publisher=Foreign Affairs and International Trade Canada |date=December 2006 |url=http://www.international.gc.ca/enviro/energy-energie/facts-faits.aspx?lang=eng |accessdate=2008-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520092655/http://www.international.gc.ca/enviro/energy-energie/facts-faits.aspx?lang=eng |archivedate=May 20, 2011 }}</ref>
The [[United States]] is Canada's major trade market for energy products and services. Canada sends around 98% of its total energy exports to the United States, meaning that Canada is the largest supplier of energy exports to the world's largest economy. Canada also exports significant amounts of uranium and coal to Asia, Europe and Latin America.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Canada Energy Policy Laws and Regulation Handbook|publisher=International Business Publication, USA|year=2015|isbn=9781312950481|location=Washington DC|pages=39}}</ref>
Despite being a net energy exporter, Canada also imports large/small amounts of energy products.<ref name="CEF_GC" />
Canada has a robust energy profile with abundant and diverse resources. The energy and climate policies in Canada are interrelated. These energy and climate policies are implemented at both the federal and provincial government level. The federal government is responsible for establishing objectives for the entire country and the provincial governments are responsible for enforcing these objectives and developing the methods to achieve these goals.<ref name="Fertel">{{cite journal|last1=Fertel|first1=Camille|title=Canadian energy and climate policies: A SWOT analysis in search of federal/provincial coherence|journal=Energy Policy|date=2013|volume=63|pages=1139–1150|doi=10.1016/j.enpol.2013.09.057}}</ref> In 2015, the federal and provincial governments created a national agreement for cooperating in boosting the nation's energy industry while transitioning to a low-carbon economy.<ref name="Laverty">{{cite journal|last1=Laverty|first1=Gene|title=Canada's Provincial leaders reach agreement on energy strategy|journal=SNL Energy Power Daily|date=Jul 20, 2015|pages=1–3}}</ref> Today, provincial governments are developing their own strategies in order to reach the national goals. The Prince Edward Island Strategy is one of the first provincial strategies developed in response to the federal agreement goals.<ref name="PEI">{{cite web|title=Prince Edward Island Provincial Energy Strategy 2016/17|accessdate=17 September 2017}}</ref>
